instruction: [INST] Analyze this file to learn MacBook motherboard repair. The 'definitions' section explains key technical terms. The 'threads' section contains real-world repair discussions. Use both sections to understand and learn how to troubleshoot MacBook issues. Posts from username 'larossmann' , 'dukefawks' , and '2informaticos' are posts from trusted experts.[/INST]

definitions.A1425: What is A1425? A1425 is a model number for a 13 inch size MacBook Pro Retina from years Early 2013, Late 2012 with EMC 2672, that may contain one of these boards depending on the year & configuration: 820-3190, 820-3462..
definitions.820-3462: What is 820-3462? a LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER.
definitions.PPBUS_G3H: What is PPBUS_G3H? Main system power rail that charges the battery, or is power from the battery, that everything else is powered from. .
definitions.PP3V42_G3H: What is PP3V42_G3H? PP3V42_G3H is a power rail present when the machine is in a G3H global system hardware off state and is the first rail that should be generated in Macbooks that use it. .
definitions.PPDCIN_G3H: What is PPDCIN_G3H? PPDCIN_G3H Is a power rail that comes directly from the laptop charger..
definitions.PP3V3_S0: What is PP3V3_S0? The "PP3V3_S0" rail in a MacBook logic board is a power rail that supplies 3.3 volts to the system when it is fully awake (S0 state). .
definitions.PP5V5_S5: What is PP5V5_S5? This is a typo of PP5V_S5 When you see PP5V_S5, assume they meant to type PP5V_S5.
definitions.U7000: What is U7000? U7000 refers to the ISL6258 or ISL6259 charging IC on Macbooks from 2008-2012.
definitions.U5701: What is U5701? this is the keyboard controller chip that takes the keyboard and trackpad input and turns it into a USB device signal for the machine to process. If replacing a keyboard doesnâ€™t fix an issue with keys not typing, check all traces between keyboard connector and this IC. This chip has programming so it must be replaced from a similar, ideally identical board. .
definitions.SMC_TPAD_RST_L: What is SMC_TPAD_RST_L? SMC_TPAD_RST_L is a signal that comes from the trackpad that can reset the SMC when it is low.  _L means whatever before the _L in the signal name is asserted when it is low voltage, such as 0.0v to 0.5v. The trackpad having corrosion from liquid damage is a very common cause of no light on the magsafe charger & the system not turning on, when the trackpad or trackpad cable is corroded and holding this line down. .
definitions.WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD: What is WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD? This is a signal from the keyboard for the left shift key, which is significantly different from the right shift key when it comes to resetting the SMC/PRAM. .

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Hi all.
I have a Macbook Pro <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> that gets an orange light, no fans or other signs of life.
No signs of overheating.
Very slight amount of corrosion, all located on bottom side edge of the board (when installed in MB). 
Between L7560 and across to around <CHIP>U6990</CHIP>.
<CAPACITOR>C7527</CAPACITOR> looked the worse -bad corrosion, and actually broke free while cleaning it.

I think the board is a <LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, and it does indeed look identical to the boardview, I just cannot find the model on the board itself.

The only consistent power supply is <SIGNAL>PP3V32_G3H</SIGNAL>, which is a stable 3.41volts.
All the rest were fluctuating.

I suspect there is a short, and the PSU or board itself is cycling on and off to protect it... and hence why nothing is getting hot enough to notice.
Any suggestions on which rail/area to check first?
Thanks for any help you can provide.

<SIGNAL>PPDCIN_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating slightly 14.75-15.15V
<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating slightly 15.09-15.5V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> Fluctuating 0.10-1.0V
<SIGNAL>PP3V3_S0</SIGNAL> Fluctuating 0.20-1.0V
<SIGNAL>PP5V5_S0</SIGNAL> 0v
<SIGNAL>PP5V5_S5</SIGNAL> 3.9-5.02V
<SIGNAL>PP3V42_G3H</SIGNAL> 3.41V

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
"<SIGNAL>PPBUS_G3H</SIGNAL> fluctuating slightly 15.09-15.5V"
Looks like shorted <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR>, change it.
Be sure R/<CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> are both good, as all traces around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Thanks 2inforaticos.
I appreciate your help, once again.

OK, I desoldered <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and checked the desoldered chip.
All pins/pads on the removed <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> show essentially zero ohms resistance, so you were correct re it being shorted.
<RESISTOR>R7025</RESISTOR> shows zero Ohms.
<CAPACITOR>C7025</CAPACITOR> seems OK.

I did find a tiny bit of corrosion near <CHIP>U7000</CHIP>, primarily on <CAPACITOR>C7000</CAPACITOR>, but otherwise area around <CHIP>U7000</CHIP> looks good.

I don't think I have the same board to grab a replacement <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> from. :(
I may have to order one in.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
You should find it on other MaBook boards.
Just check schematics of the scrap boards available.
The pin layout is the match you search for.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Hi again 2informaticos, and thanks again for your help.
Sorry for the delayed reply - first day back at work since the mid December.

I replaced <TRANSISTOR>Q7030</TRANSISTOR> and now have the unit booting. :)

One thing that isn't working is the left Shift key.
HOWEVER, the SMC correctly resets by pressing the left Shift, Control, Option and power buttons - i.e. the magsafe light changes from orange to green and back to orange, so it must be at least partially working?

However, I notice that it is booting in Safe mode most of the time?
I did an SMC reset and it booted normally, but seems to intermittently boot into safe mode.
I assume that the shift key may be stuck down - although when in OSX, the characters type in lower case unless I press the right Shift?
Once in OSX, after logging in, the red Safe mode up the top right disappears, I only see it on the login screen.
I'm not familiar with safe mode as to whether this is standard behaviour.

Short of replacing the keyboard/kb& top cover, any suggestions?
Thanks again for any help and advice.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Search for "keyboard tester" in Google and you will find several webpages for testing all the keys.
I prefer to use
[URL unfurl="true"]https://en.key-test.ru/[/URL]

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Hi again 2informaticos.

Thanks for the link to the keyboard tester.

Yes, the left shift doesn't respond.
However using it to do an SMC works, so not sure whats going on there.

Either way, customer is happy to take it as it is - so job closed... for now at least. :)

Thanks again for your help.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Possibly issue with <CHIP>U5750</CHIP>.
It processes <SIGNAL>WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KBD</SIGNAL>, because generates <SIGNAL>SMC_TPAD_RST_L</SIGNAL>.
But may fail <SIGNAL>WS_LEFT_SHIFT_KEY</SIGNAL> generation, or there is broken trace between <CHIP>U5750</CHIP> and <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>.

threads.title: <MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER>A1425</MACBOOK MODEL NUMBER> (<LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>820-3462</LOGIC BOARD PART NUMBER>-A, I think) with most power rails fluctuating.
threads.message:
Thanks for that additional information.
That makes sense....if it comes back I'll have a look at <CHIP>U5750</CHIP>, and or traces between it and <CHIP>U5701</CHIP>
Thanks again.
